docs.lead_paragraph: The Group of Six is over, done. What's left is the Group of One: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine. Ms. Snowe, below, is the only member of her party on the Senate Finance Committee willing to consider supporting the proposed health care legislation. The other Republicans on that panel will vote against it, and so on Wednesday internal policy fights among Democrats will move to the forefront.
docs.abstract: Republican Sen Olympia J Snowe is only member of her party on Senate Finance Committee willing to consider supporting proposed health care legislation; other Republicans on panel will vote against health bill, and so internal policy fights among Democrats will move to forefront; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: George Halvorson, the chief executive of one of the nation's most respected health care systems, Kaiser Permanente, says he is hopeful that all the sausage-making in Washington will succeed in squeezing out a law. ''I'm optimistic because, A, we need reform and, B, the president needs the bill,'' Mr. Halvorson said in an interview Tuesday.
docs.abstract: George Halvorson, chief executive of one of nation's most respected health care systems Kaiser Permanente, says he is hopeful that federal lawmakers will succeed in coming up with health care legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling sorry for insurance company executives? Then you can weep along with a new online advertisement. ''Health insurance executives are getting a bad rap,'' an actor laments on screen. Says another, visibly shaken: ''People are saying a lot of mean things about health insurance companies and their executives. And it's got to stop.''
docs.abstract: Comedian Will Ferrell and liberal advocacy group MoveOn.org release online ad that is spoof featuring several actors pretending to stand up for health insurance executives; photo (M)
